title: Can a D student get into grad school? - Quora

response.answer_text: If you’re a D student you probably didn’t graduate from college. Most accredited colleges in the US require a cumulative GPA of 2.000 or greater to graduate. An undergraduate degree is almost always a requirement to get into grad school. Exceptions to this are things like a longtime demonstrated world-class proficiency in some subject of interest. More to the point for the average ‘D student’ is the idea that college performance falls off fairly quickly in terms of relative importance in admission criteria for grad school. If you graduated in May and are applying for September admission, forget about it. If, on the other hand, you graduated ten years ago and have ten years of good work experience with increasing levels of responsibility to show, it’s much more likely you can get in. There are two things to consider here. First, pick a local state university rather than a flagship university with a worldwide reputation. The flagship schools have more applicants with perfect records than they can admit, so they are unlikely to go out of their way for a nonstandard applicant. Second, you have got to take the personal initiative to get past the first thing the admissions office will do, which is to see if you meet the GPA requirement and look no further if you don’t, This may take the form of talking to someone in the department you’re thinking of applying to so that the department can make sure your application gets a full evaluation.

A2A. Can a D student get into grad school? If you are talking about D, 1.0 on a 4.0 scale where a C, 2.0, is necessary for a bachelor’s degree, then no, because a bachelor’s degree is required for admissions. If you are talking about a student with a bachelor’s degree where the student’s GPA is D, 1.0, then may be because some graduate school have program that only require a bachelor’s degree.

I suppose it might be possible, but in my experience it would be highly unlikely. The best thing you can do is either try for another degree and get better grades, or retake the classes you did poorly in. You can get excellent advice from the admissions advisors at any major university. They will help you understand what you might need to do next.

If that’s “D” for “Distinction” in the common Australian university grading system (Conceded Pass < Pass < Credit < Distinction < High Distinction) then yes, that’s more than you need to get into a Masters degree and may be enough to gain admittance to a PhD if you have other relevant achievements, such as papers already published in good journals. If you mean D in an ABCD grading system, then probably not.

No - because a D student can’t graduate from college. Most schools will dismiss a student after a couple of semesters on academic probation (which D work will certainly qualify you for). You have to be a graduate to go to graduate school.

I have never worked at an institution that allowed a student to earn a bachelor’s degree with either a cumulative or in-major GPA below 2.0, so like Peter De Vroede, I can’t see it happening. Can a student with one D earn a graduate degree? Sure, but the more grades below B and the lower the GPA, the less competitive you become.

If you have primarily minimal passes or barely passing on your college transcript, it indicates you are not meeting requirements to graduate a bachelors. As all bachelors require at least an average or satisfactory performance, and imply you have not met minimum requirements in college. As a job, it suggests you have not mastered the material for the average college student, and that your overall or major work can improve. Overall, it implies you are not ready for graduate work in the same major or field. And that you can improve the grades in the courses, where you have received lower quality assessments. It’s better to improve lower graded courses, work in an experience, or somehow balance the lower quality. As that study of the material will carry with you implicitly, and effect studies where you must apply the basic principles, methods, or facts there.
Maybe, but not into anything remotely considered a good school. The first question you need to ask is if a D student can even get a Bachelor’s Degree. Not stupid my schools.

Tricky. There would be a lot of “It depends” in that scenario. Master's or doctorate? Do you have support of a prospective faculty member? Are there clear extenuating circumstances? Do you have a high GRE score? But ultimately, the the people to ask are grad program coordinators of places you are interested in, not random people on Quora.
